properties.name: Banyan tree on Rang Hill
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp The twisted limbs of a banyan tree on Rang Hill

properties.name: China Inn Café
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp The China Inn Café is in a converted shop house, allowing the visitor to appreciate the unusual design of these buildings - small street frontage, but stretching back a long way. The food\'s good and reasonably priced, and owner Khun Noi is a delightful person. Definitely the place for refreshments during a walk around the old town.

properties.name: Koh Sim Bee Statue
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp There are two hills in Phuket Town - Rang Hill and Toh Sae Hill. There\'s a pleasant park at the top of Rang Hill, presided over by a statue of the portly Koh Sim Bee, Lord Rassada, the governor of Phuket and other parts about 100 years ago. He built roads, introduced rubber planting and brought in big Western mining companies to extract tin more efficiently, all of which brought a boom in prosperity to Phuket - though at a cost to the island\'s environment; opencast tin mining left areas of Phuket looking like a moonscape, and dredging took a heavy toll on local fish stocks. Nevertheless, Koh Sim Bee is still revered and his methods are still studied by government officials.

properties.name: Phra Pitak Chinpracha Mansion
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp The largest mansion in Phuket built with tin money, the Phra Pitak Chinpracha Mansion is still in private hands. Though it looks most attractive from the road ir is by all accounts crumbling inside. Rumours of a sale with a possible conversion to a 50-star boutique hotel have all come to nothing. Sad.

properties.name: Rang Hill
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp From the top of Rang Hill there are fine views of Phuket Town and the sea beyond.

properties.name: Robinson Department Store
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp Robinson was Phuket\'s first department store. It has since been overshadowed by Central Festival on the outskirts of the city and Jungceylon in Patong

properties.name: Salvatore - Italian Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp Super Italian Restaurant at 15 Rasada Rd, Tel 076-225958

properties.name: Soi Romanee - the old entertainment quarter
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp 100 years ago, when tin mining, not tourism, ruled in Phuket, Soi Romanee was the entertainment centre for the tin miners - bars and girls brought in from Russia, China, all over. The owners of the tin mines were also the owners of many opf the establishments on Soi Romanee and nearby. As one marveled, "We pay the workers on Friday afternoon and in the evening we get the money back." These days it\'s rather quieter. After many years of neglect the Sino-Portuguese buildings are being gentrified, with bars, cafes, craft shops and offices opening. Some nights there\'s free live jazz in the street and once a year there\'s a big street party (see pic) with a Chinese flavour. Oh yes, there is still one brothel, at the north end. But it\'s pretty sad looking.

properties.name: Soi Romanee revival
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp In the past few years many buildings on Soi Romanee have been very attractively renovated. The street is also unique in Phuket in that the power lines have been buried - a great improvement. The current Mayor of Phuket Town was born in a house in this road, which may or may not have something to do with it...

properties.name: Thai Hua Museum
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp The Thai Hua Museum is in the former Thai Hua School, a private school founded by and for the local Chinese community. It houses good displays about the Straits Chinese culture.

properties.name: The old post office
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp When a new Post Office was built in the 1960s, the old one, built around 1910, was left to decay. About 7 years ago it was carefully restored and is now a museum of Thai philately.

properties.name: Tourism Authority of Thailand
properties.description: Posted by Phukethelp The TAT built new offices a couple of years ago. The design is Sino-Portuguese, in keeping with much older buildings in Phuket Town. Service is smiling and pleasant, but language can be a problem...
